CARDINAL . The ORG claim may be summarised as follows :
( a ) for the litigation in the LANGUAGE courts ( " the LANGUAGE costs " ) : QUANTITY ;
( b ) for the proceedings before the ORG and ORG ( " the GPE costs " ) :
- MONEY up to the delivery of the judgment of DATE ;
- an additional amount in respect of LAW CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) proceedings ;
( c ) interest at PERCENT per annum on the sums awarded .

There was appended to the applicants’ observations of DATE a schedule with particulars of the quantified items , incurred since DATE . For ease of reference , relevant details are included below in the section " As to the law " .
CARDINAL . The costs of the litigation in GPE had been the subject of certain " without prejudice " correspondence . On DATE the Legal Adviser to ORG had written to the ORG Solicitor as follows :
" ... I am writing to you now to see whether the matter of costs could be dealt with by agreement , thus avoiding any argument at the resumed hearing , when judgment is given .
I do not think you will be surprised to hear that we expect ORG to find in favour of the Attorney - general ...

In normal circumstances it would be difficult to resist the argument that costs should follow the event , but I venture to suggest that there are a number of features about the present case which would justify a departure from the normal rule ... "

There followed a list of circumstances surrounding the litigation in the LANGUAGE courts , together with an assertion that ORG had acted " with great restraint and responsibility " and had " frequently subordinated its private interest to the more general public interest " .
The letter concluded :

" ... we ... base our suggestion that it should be agreed that , in the event of a judgment by ORG in favour of the Attorney - General , there should be an agreed Order that each side pay their own costs , both in ORG and in the courts below , on the ... grounds which I have outlined above . "
The Deputy ORG Solicitor had replied on DATE :

" I have obtained the instructions of the Attorney - General on your letter of DATE . He considers that each party should bear their own costs of all the proceedings , whatever the outcome of the appeal to ORG . "

CARDINAL . On DATE , that is DATE after giving judgment on the merits in favour of the Attorney - General , ORG ordered : " That , by consent , each party do bear and pay their own costs here and below . " Counsel for the Attorney - General had pointed out that " in the ordinary way the Attorney - General would have asked for costs " but that , in the circumstances , it had " been agreed that each party should pay their own costs " ; no observations had been added on behalf of ORG .

CARDINAL . In LANGUAGE law , a litigant must bear his own costs unless the court otherwise orders . An award of costs lies within the discretion of the court but , as a general rule and in the absence of special factors , " costs follow the event " : the unsuccessful party will be ordered to pay to his opponent the latter ’s costs , although the actual amount recoverable will be assessed by the court and will very rarely cover the full expenditure . There is jurisdiction to award costs against a successful party but it is exercisable only in the most exceptional circumstances ( see PERSON v. PERSON [ DATE ] CARDINAL All England Law Reports CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . An order by consent made by an NORP court is not a contract , but it is sufficient evidence of the contract upon which it is based . Such an order , like the contract which it evidences , is not necessarily to be read literally but is to be construed in the light of any admissible evidence of surrounding circumstances , including evidence as to the nature of the dispute compromised by the order ( per Mr. Justice PERSON and , on appeal , per Lord Justice PERSON in ORG and ORG [ DATE ] ORG , vol .
